definitions: composed of many cells working together as a functional organism
consisting of multiple specialized cells that form tissues and organs
examples: Multicellular organisms evolved from simple single-celled ancestors
The multicellular structure allows specialized functions in different tissues
Scientists study multicellular development in laboratory conditions
These multicellular plants exhibit complex reproductive strategies

definitions: displaying or decorated with several different colors in combination
examples: The multicolored butterfly landed on the garden flowers
She wore a beautiful multicolored scarf around her neck

definitions: relating to or containing several cultural or ethnic groups within society
examples: The multicultural festival celebrated traditions from around the world
Toronto is known as a highly multicultural city

definitions: having or involving several dimensions, aspects, or features simultaneously
existing in or involving more than three spatial dimensions mathematically
examples: The research takes a multidimensional approach to solving poverty
Her multidimensional personality makes her interesting to know
The physicist studied multidimensional space-time models
This multidimensional array stores complex data structures

definitions: composed of or relating to various different ethnic groups together
examples: The multiethnic neighborhood celebrates many cultural festivals
They formed a multiethnic coalition to address community issues

definitions: having many different aspects, features, or sides to consider comprehensively
examples: The multifaceted problem requires input from various experts
Her multifaceted career spans both business and the arts

definitions: agreed upon or participated in by three or more parties or nations
examples: The multilateral trade agreement benefits all participating countries
They sought multilateral cooperation on climate change issues

definitions: consisting of or arranged in several different levels or tiers physically or conceptually
examples: The multilevel parking garage can accommodate hundreds of cars
They implemented a multilevel marketing strategy for expansion

definitions: able to speak or written in several different languages fluently
examples: The multilingual translator works with six different languages
This multilingual dictionary includes translations in five languages

definitions: operating in or involving several different countries or their citizens
examples: The multinational corporation has offices in fifty countries
They formed a multinational peacekeeping force for the region

definitions: having or involving several parts, elements, or members simultaneously
containing another number an exact number of times without remainder
examples: She suffered multiple injuries in the accident
The research revealed multiple causes for the phenomenon
Twelve is a multiple of both three and four
Find all multiple values of six under fifty

definitions: increased by mathematical multiplication to produce a larger result
made much greater in number, amount, or intensity through repetition
examples: The multiplied numbers gave an unexpectedly large result
Her multiplied efforts finally produced the desired outcome
Their multiplied troubles seemed to have no end
The multiplied effects of poverty impact entire communities

definitions: designed or suitable for several different uses or functions simultaneously
examples: The multipurpose room serves as both gym and auditorium
She bought a multipurpose tool for camping trips

definitions: composed of or involving people of many different racial backgrounds
examples: The multiracial family celebrates diverse cultural traditions together
America is becoming an increasingly multiracial society

definitions: unwilling to speak or remaining silent about something deliberately
examples: She kept mum about the surprise party plans
The witness remained mum during police questioning

definitions: lacking interest or excitement; concerned with ordinary daily matters
of this earthly world rather than spiritual or heavenly matters
examples: She grew tired of her mundane office routine
The mundane tasks consumed most of their working day
The monk left behind mundane concerns for spiritual contemplation
They discussed mundane matters rather than philosophical questions

definitions: of or relating to a town or city government and services
examples: The municipal building houses all city government offices
Municipal workers maintain the city parks and streets

definitions: painted or applied directly on a wall or ceiling surface
examples: The mural painting depicts scenes from local history
Artists created beautiful mural art throughout the neighborhood

definitions: killed unlawfully and with premeditated malice by another person
examples: The murdered victim was found in the abandoned warehouse
Police investigated the case of the murdered businessman

definitions: capable of, intending, or involving murder or extreme violence
extremely arduous, difficult, or unpleasant in intensity or degree
examples: The killer had a murderous look in his eyes
They stopped his murderous rampage before more were hurt
The murderous heat made outdoor work nearly impossible
She maintained a murderous pace throughout the marathon

definitions: dark and gloomy, especially due to thick mist or muddy water
not fully explained or understood; questionable, suspicious, or dishonest
examples: The divers couldn't see through the murky water
A murky fog rolled in from the harbor
The company has a murky past with several scandals
The details of the agreement remain murky

definitions: having well-developed muscles; strong and physically powerful in build
vigorous, forceful, and robust in style, action, or expression
examples: The muscular athlete lifted the heavy weights easily
His muscular arms showed years of physical training
The president gave a muscular defense of the policy
They need a more muscular approach to enforcement

definitions: relating to or accompanied by music; skilled in or fond of music
having a pleasant sound like music; melodious or harmonious in quality
examples: She has exceptional musical talent on the piano
The musical performance delighted the audience
Her musical voice carried beautifully across the hall
The birds created a musical symphony at dawn

definitions: absorbed in thought; reflecting deeply or dreamily on something
examples: She sat with a musing expression on her face
His musing manner suggested deep philosophical thoughts

definitions: absolutely necessary, required, or indispensable; not to be missed
examples: This book is must reading for history students
The new restaurant is a must visit destination

definitions: liable to change; capable of or subject to alteration or variation
examples: Human opinions are mutable and shift with experience
The mutable nature of fashion makes prediction difficult

definitions: resulting from or showing the effect of genetic mutation or change
examples: Scientists studied the mutant genes in laboratory mice
The mutant strain showed resistance to the disease

definitions: unable to speak due to physical inability or unwillingness
characterized by absence of sound; silent, quiet, or subdued
examples: The mute child communicated through sign language
She stood mute before the accusations
The television remained on mute during their conversation
His mute protest went unnoticed by management

definitions: softened, subdued, or made less intense in sound or color
restrained in expression, lacking intensity, or deliberately understated
examples: The muted colors created a calming atmosphere
She spoke in muted tones during the ceremony
The market showed a muted response to the news
His muted enthusiasm suggested underlying concerns

definitions: inflicted with violent and disfiguring injury; severely damaged or destroyed
examples: The mutilated statue was barely recognizable
Investigators found mutilated documents in the office

definitions: refusing to obey authority; showing rebellious opposition to leadership
examples: The mutinous crew refused to follow captain's orders
Her mutinous attitude disrupted the entire team meeting

definitions: experienced or done by two or more parties toward each other equally
examples: They ended their relationship by mutual agreement
The mutual respect between them was evident

definitions: countless or extremely great in number; having innumerable aspects or elements
examples: The night sky displayed myriad stars
She faced myriad challenges in her new position

definitions: difficult or impossible to understand, explain, or identify clearly
intentionally keeping information secret or maintaining an enigmatic manner
examples: The mysterious illness baffled medical experts
Strange mysterious sounds came from the attic
He maintained a mysterious silence about his past
Her mysterious smile suggested hidden knowledge

definitions: relating to mystics or religious mysticism; spiritually allegorical or symbolic
examples: The mystic symbols adorned the ancient temple walls
He studied mystic traditions from various cultures

definitions: relating to ancient religious mysteries or occult rites and practices
inspiring a sense of spiritual mystery, awe, and fascination
examples: The monks pursued mystical union with the divine
She studied mystical texts from medieval times
The forest had a mystical quality in moonlight
His paintings convey a mystical sense of connection

definitions: having qualities suitable to myth; legendary, heroic, or supernatural
examples: The athlete achieved mythic status after winning gold
His mythic journey inspired generations of adventurers

definitions: occurring in myths or folk tales; lacking factual existence
existing only in imagination; fictitious, invented, or fabricated
examples: Dragons are mythical creatures from ancient stories
The mythical city of Atlantis fascinates researchers
His mythical expertise proved completely unfounded
The mythical profits never materialized

definitions: relating to, based on, or appearing in myths or mythology
examples: The museum displayed mythological artifacts from ancient Greece
She studied mythological themes in Renaissance art

definitions: persistently annoying or finding fault in a harassing way
persistently painful or worrying; continuously troublesome
examples: His nagging complaints disrupted the entire meeting
She couldn't stand her nagging mother-in-law
A nagging pain in her shoulder kept her awake
He had nagging doubts about the decision

definitions: showing lack of experience, wisdom, or judgment; innocently simple
examples: Her naive trust in strangers worried her parents
The naive investor lost money on obvious scams

definitions: without clothes; having no covering or clothing on the body
exposed to harm; without defense, concealment, or disguise
examples: The naked statue stood in the museum gallery
He was caught naked in the swimming pool
Her naked ambition alienated her colleagues
The naked truth was difficult to accept

definitions: having no name or not identified by name; anonymous
too horrible or disturbing to specify or describe in words
examples: The nameless donor gave millions to charity
A nameless fear gripped the entire village
They faced nameless horrors in the wilderness
A nameless dread filled her heart

definitions: involved in or relating to the act of giving names
examples: The naming ceremony attracted the whole family
They established naming conventions for the database

definitions: having a fuzzy, kinky, or tightly curled texture, especially of hair
examples: The fabric had a soft nappy texture
His nappy hair required special care products

definitions: having excessive interest in or admiration of oneself and one's appearance
examples: His narcissistic behavior alienated all his friends
The narcissistic leader ignored all criticism

definitions: relating to or denoting drugs that relieve pain and induce sleep
examples: The doctor prescribed narcotic painkillers after surgery
Narcotic substances are strictly controlled by law

definitions: in the form of or concerned with narration or storytelling
examples: The narrative structure of the novel was complex
She used narrative techniques to explain the data

definitions: of small width in relation to length; confined within limits
limited in extent, amount, or scope; restricted in range
denoting a victory, escape, or defeat by a small margin
examples: The narrow alley between buildings was dark
A narrow path wound through the mountains
His narrow experience limited his perspective
They focused on a narrow range of topics
She had a narrow escape from the accident
The team won by a narrow margin

definitions: reduced in width, extent, or scope; made less broad
examples: Her narrowed eyes showed suspicion
The narrowed focus improved research efficiency
